questions.question: Which system is widely used for reporting thyroid cytopathology?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Bethesda System Explanation: The Bethesda System for Reporting Thyroid Cytopathology (TBSRTC) is a standardised reporting system designed to classify thyroid Fine-Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC) biopsy results. The system includes six diagnostic categories, ranging from non-diagnostic/unsatisfactory to malignant. The Bethesda System for Reporting Thyroid Cytopathology Diagnostic category Risk of malignancy (%) Usual management Non-diagnostic 5-20 Repeat FNAC with ultrasound guidance Benign 2-7 Clinical and sonographic follow-up Atypia of undetermined significance 13-30 Repeat FNAC, molecular testing, diagnostic lobectomy, or surveillance Follicular neoplasm 23-34 Molecular testing, diagnostic lobectomy Suspicious for malignancy 67-83 Molecular testing, lobectomy, or near-total thyroidectomy Malignant 97-100 Lobectomy or near-total thyroidectomy The Bethesda system is also used to report cervical cytology. TIRADS (Thyroid Imaging Reporting and Data System) (Option A) is a classification system for reporting thyroid ultrasound findings, not cytopathology. Gleason’s System (Option B) is used to grade prostate cancer based on histological patterns. Duke Classification (Option D) is a system for staging colorectal cancer. Reference: The Bethesda System for Reporting Thyroid Cytopathology, 3rd Edition, Page 4

questions.question: You are examining a high-resolution microscopic image of thyroid tissue. Which of the following depicts cells responsible for the secretion of calcitonin?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) B Explanation: Parafollicular cells responsible for calcitonin secretion are indicated by ‘B’ in the given image. C-cells secrete the hormone calcitonin (Hypocalcemic Hormone). C-cells (Parafollicular Cells) cells are columnar with basally located nuclei. Follicular Cells (Option A) have a round nucleus and basophilic cytoplasm. Their function is to synthesize thyroid hormones. Colloid (Option C) is a gel-like substance that appears pinkish and homogeneous in the follicles and serves as a reservoir for thyroid hormones. Stromal Cells (Option D) fill up spaces between the follicles and connective tissue, capillaries, and lymphatics. Reference: Victor P. Eroschenko - Atlas of Histology with Functional Correlations, 13th Edition, Page 771.

questions.question: A 35-year-old female presents with fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance. On physical examination, she has diffuse goitre and dry skin. Histopathological examination shows lymphoid infiltration, atrophic thyroid follicles lined in many areas by epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. It is characterised by painless enlargement of the thyroid, commonly in middle-aged women. The enlargement of the gland is generally symmetric and diffuse. In histopathology, there is extensive lymphocytic infiltration with well-developed germinal centres. The thyroid follicles are atrophic and are lined in many areas by epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm, termed Hürthle cells. Hürthle cells represent a metaplastic response of the normally low cuboidal follicular epithelium to chronic injury. The thyroid parenchyma contains a dense lymphocytic infiltrate with germinal centres.

questions.question: Which of the following antibodies are elevated in a patient of Hashimoto's thyroiditis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies (Anti-TPO) Explanation: In Hashimoto's thyroiditis, the immune system mistakenly targets the thyroid gland, leading to chronic inflammation and damage. Antibodies play a crucial role in this process. Anti-Thyroid Peroxidase (TPO) Antibodies : Target an enzyme called thyroid peroxidase, which helps synthesise thyroid hormones. They are a hallmark of Hashimoto's thyroiditis and are frequently elevated in affected individuals. Anti-Thyroglobulin(Tg) Antibodies : Thyroglobulin is a protein involved in thyroid hormone production. Antibodies against thyroglobulin can disrupt hormone synthesis and contribute to thyroid gland damage. Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI) are found in Graves' disease. (Option A) Anti-thyroid stimulating hormone receptor antibodies (Anti-TSHR): These antibodies are typically associated with autoimmune thyroid diseases such as Graves' disease. (Option C) Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 10th Edition, Pages 1077 , 1078 , 1079 Harrison’s principle of internal medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2934

questions.question: A 29-year-old lady has been experiencing loss of appetite, profuse sweating, and palpitations for the past three months. Laboratory tests conclude increased T3 and T4 levels with decreased TSH levels. A representative HPE of this condition is shown below. The most common antibodies in this condition target which of the following?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) TSH receptor Explanation: The HPE image shows features of Grave’s disease most commonly as Long-acting thyroid stimulator antibodies that target the TSH receptor. The HPE image shows the microscopic finding of Graves disease, characterised by Follicles are lined by hyperplastic, enlarged epithelial cells that project into the lumens of the follicles, forming papillary projections. These are called Pseudopapillae (vs true papillae containing a fibrovascular core). These cells actively resorb the colloid in the centres of the follicles, resulting in the scalloped appearance of the colloid's edges. Antibodies in Graves disease: TSI - Thyroid stimulating immunoglobulin or LATS - Long-acting thyroid stimulator. These antibodies attach to the TSH receptor and stimulate them, leading to excessive release of T3 and T4. This results in hyperthyroidism

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman comes to the office due to progressively worsening eye irritation and double vision over the last two months. She also reports unintentional weight loss, mood swings, diarrhoea, and palpitations. Physical examination shows tachycardia and bilateral proptosis. What is the pathophysiology causing proptosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Increased activity of orbital fibroblasts Explanation: This patient with hyperthyroidism (weight loss, palpitations, tachycardia) and significant ophthalmopathy (proptosis, diplopia) has Graves disease with ophthalmopathy, which is due to increased activity of orbital fibroblasts. Graves disease is an autoimmune disorder triggered by thyrotropin receptor antibodies that activate the TSH receptor. The TSH receptor is also on fibroblasts, adipocytes, and other cell types. Triad in Graves: Hyperthyroidism Proptosis Pretibial myxoedema- infiltrative dermopathy due to thickening of the dermis due to deposition of glycosaminoglycans and lymphocyte infiltration Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 10th Edition, Pages 1081-1082

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the gross morphology of Riedel’s thyroiditis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Stony and hard consistency. Explanation: Riedel's Thyroiditis belongs to an IgG4-related disease that causes extensive fibrosis. Fibrosis causes the thyroid to become stony and hard. It also attaches the thyroid to the adjacent tissues, muscles, and vessels implying the mass is fixed and does not move with deglutition. So it behaves like/mimics a cancer. Other IgG4-related diseases include: Mikulicz syndrome- Affects salivary and lacrimal gland Kuttner syndrome- Sclerosis of the submandibular gland Ormond disease- Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis Angiocentric fibrosis- Involves nasal cavity Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page 1081

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis?

options.B: Usually presents as a painful enlargement of the thyroid

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Usually presents as a painful enlargement of the thyroid Explanation: Subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis is typically a painless enlargement of the thyroid. Usually presents postpartum in 5% of women and is presumed to have an autoimmune aetiology. The self-limiting condition does not usually require treatment Characterised by lymphocytic inflammation in the thyroid. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page 1080

questions.question: What is the finding in the histopathological examination of a biopsy specimen from a patient with De Quervain Thyroiditis?

options.A: Extensive stromal fibrosis extending beyond the thyroid capsule
options.C: Mononuclear infiltration with well-developed germinal centres
options.D: Mixed cellular infiltration with occasional multinucleated giant cells

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Mixed cellular infiltration with occasional multinucleated giant cells de Quervain thyroiditis. The microscopic findings include: Large multinucleated giant cells Giant cells with engulfed colloid Mixed cellular infiltration Reference: De Quervain Thyroiditis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient presents with a solitary thyroid nodule. The patient also reports difficulty swallowing, with no complaints of weight loss, fatigue, or heat intolerance. An excisional biopsy reveals >75% of the following characteristic cells. Which genetic mutation is most commonly associated with this type of thyroid tumour?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) RAS Explanation: The above image shows cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and small regular nuclei, suggesting Hurthle cells. The presence of >75% of these cells indicates a Hurthle cell tumour, a rare thyroid neoplasm of follicular cell origin associated with RAS mutation. Hurthle cell adenomas are variants of follicular adenoma, and the presence of more than 75% of Hurthle cells is a key diagnostic feature. Hürthle cell (oxyphil) adenoma comprises cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and small regular nuclei. Thyroid Malignancy Mutations/Genetic Alterations Follicular Thyroid Adenoma ( Benign Condition) RAS Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma (PTC) BRAF V600E RET/PTC rearrangements Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma (FTC) RAS PAX8-PPAR γ rearrangements PIK3CA Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC) RET Anaplastic Thyroid Carcinoma (ATC) TP53

questions.question: Match each type of thyroid tumour with its most commonly associated risk factor: Thyroid Carcinoma Risk Factors: 1. Papillary thyroid carcinoma A. Iodine deficiency 2. Follicular thyroid carcinoma B. RET proto-oncogene mutations 3. Medullary thyroid carcinoma C. Radiation exposure 4. Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A)1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-D Explanation: Thyroid Cancer Type Risk Factors Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma Radiation exposure (especially in childhood) Family history of thyroid cancer Hashimoto thyroiditis Thyroglossal cyst Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma Iodine deficiency Long-standing Goiter. Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma RET proto-oncogene mutations. Family history (e.g., MEN2 syndrome) Anaplastic Thyroid Carcinoma Older age ¼ th of patients have a past history of a well-differentiated follicular neoplasm Previous radiation exposure Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 10th Edition, Pages 1086-91. https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/thyroid-cancer/symptoms-causes/syc-20354161 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4052185/

questions.question: A 40-year-old patient presents with a nodule in the anterior neck and lymphadenopathy. The tumour is found to have spread to the lymphatics. Histopathological examination shows characteristic findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is not a common feature of follicular carcinoma of thyroid?

options.D: FNAC is not helpful in diagnosis

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Commonly spreads by lymphatic route Explanation: Spread by lymphatic route is not a common feature of follicular carcinoma as they commonly spread by hematogenous route. Follicular carcinoma of thyroid is the second common malignancy of thyroid following papillary Ca. They are commonly associated with K-RAS mutation Capsular and vascular invasion on biopsy is a diagnostic feature of follicular carcinoma. FNAC is not helpful in diagnosis of follicular carcinomas. Regional lymph nodes are typically not involved and hematogenous spread to bone, lungs and liver are more common. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 1059-1090.

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with a painless lump on the front of the neck, bone pain, fatigue, and episodes of flushed skin. Genetic studies reveal a mutation in the RET gene. Which type of amyloid is typically deposited in this condition? β
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) A-CAL Explanation: The given scenario and mutation are associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, which has amyloid deposition derived from calcitonin, known as A-CAL. Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is a neuroendocrine tumour arising from parafollicular C cells. They secrete calcitonin, which regulates calcium levels and is also a marker for diagnosis and postoperative follow-up. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a marker in which calcitonin is negative. They can be sporadic or associated with familial syndromes like MEN 2. Both have associated RET mutations. Sporadic tumours usually present with solitary nodules whereas familial ones are characterised by bilaterality and multicentricity, and can have features of other associated tumours. A biopsy would show amyloid deposits (Acal) derived from calcitonin polypeptides. A- β ( Option A) : It is associated with Alzheimer's disease. A-L (Option C) : Is associated with primary amyloidosis and multiple myeloma, derived from immunoglobulin light chains. A-TTR ( Option D) : It is associated with transthyretin and is seen in conditions like familial amyloid polyneuropathy and senile systemic amyloidosis. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pages 261, 1091.
